articles.headline: 39 Vietnamese Died in a U.K. Truck. 18,000 More Endure This Perilous Trip.
articles.snippet: Thousands of people from Vietnam are smuggled to Europe every year on a route filled with violence and hardship. And that is just the beginning.
articles.abstract: Thousands of people from Vietnam are smuggled to Europe every year on a route filled with violence and hardship. And that is just the beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Vietnamese smugglers call it the “CO2” route: a poorly ventilated, oxygen-deficient trip across the English Channel in shipping containers or trailers piled high with pallets of merchandise, the last leg of a perilous, 6,000-mile trek across Asia and into Western Europe.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: Barneys Is Sold for Scrap, Ending an Era
articles.snippet: The bankruptcy saga of the famed New York department store involved last-minute alliances and vain attempts to cobble together competing bids.
articles.abstract: The bankruptcy saga of the famed New York department store involved last-minute alliances and vain attempts to cobble together competing bids.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Barneys New York epitomized a certain kind of aspirational Manhattan cool.
articles.byline: By Vanessa Friedman and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Uber Fights to Get Its Edge Back
articles.snippet: Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber’s chief executive, is pushing employees to do more with less and to perform better, as he battles skepticism over the ride-hailing firm’s business.
articles.abstract: Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber’s chief executive, is pushing employees to do more with less and to perform better, as he battles skepticism over the ride-hailing firm’s business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A few days after Uber went public in May and its stock fell into a tailspin, the ride-hailing company’s chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, sent a rallying message to employees.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger

articles.headline: TikTok Said to Be Under National Security Review
articles.snippet: The review comes after lawmakers raised concerns about TikTok’s growing influence in the United States.
articles.abstract: The review comes after lawmakers raised concerns about TikTok’s growing influence in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States government has opened a national security review of a Chinese company’s acquisition of the American company that became TikTok, the hugely popular short-form video app, according to people briefed on the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Mike Isaac and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Trump’s Opposition to ‘Endless Wars’ Appeals to Those Who Fought Them
articles.snippet: A majority of veterans regret the wars fought after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. President Trump and Congress are listening.
articles.abstract: A majority of veterans regret the wars fought after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. President Trump and Congress are listening.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tyler Wade was awarded the Purple Heart while serving in Afghanistan, and says he is “proud of everything” he did during his service. He also believes the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan were a mistake, as do a growing number of veterans — from retired generals to those who served across the enlisted ranks, from supporters of President Trump to “resistance” Democrats.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: The ‘Whimpering’ Terrorist Only Trump Seems to Have Heard
articles.snippet: President Trump offered a vivid account of the ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi “crying and screaming” in the final minutes before his death. The only problem: No one else knows what he’s talking about.
articles.abstract: President Trump offered a vivid account of the ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi “crying and screaming” in the final minutes before his death. The only problem: No one else knows what he’s talking about.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a vivid scene worthy of the ending of a Hollywood thriller, the image of a ruthless terrorist mastermind finally brought to justice “whimpering and crying and screaming all the way” to his death. But it may be no more true than a movie script.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Paula White, Newest White House Aide, Is a Uniquely Trumpian Pastor
articles.snippet: Ms. White, a Florida televangelist, is being brought into the Trump administration to help shore up his evangelical base — even though some Christians consider her beliefs heretical.
articles.abstract: Ms. White, a Florida televangelist, is being brought into the Trump administration to help shore up his evangelical base — even though some Christians consider her beliefs heretical.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dwight D. Eisenhower and Richard M. Nixon turned to Billy Graham, the evangelist so ubiquitous he was known as America’s Preacher. Barack Obama turned to Rick Warren, the author of “The Purpose Driven Life,” which was the best-selling nonfiction hardback in American history after the Bible.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: Adam Neumann and the Art of Failing Up
articles.snippet: WeWork’s chief risk-taker found a kindred spirit with an open checkbook: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son. Now he’s walking away from the wreckage with more than $1 billion.
articles.abstract: WeWork’s chief risk-taker found a kindred spirit with an open checkbook: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son. Now he’s walking away from the wreckage with more than $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann stood on the 57th floor of the Woolworth Building, the neo-Gothic skyscraper that was once the tallest in the world. It was late on a Friday night in 2013, and the WeWork founder and chief executive had just made a move to add the top 30 floors to his rapidly expanding real estate dealings.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Trump Stymies California Climate Efforts Even as State Burns
articles.snippet: California is feeling the brunt of climate change with more intense fires. The Trump administration is blocking the state’s efforts to fight it.
articles.abstract: California is feeling the brunt of climate change with more intense fires. The Trump administration is blocking the state’s efforts to fight it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — For the past three years, countries and companies around the world have looked to California as a counterweight to the Trump administration’s aggressive dismantling of efforts to combat climate change.

articles.headline: Warren Health Plan Tightens Democrats’ Embrace of Tax Increases
articles.snippet: A ‘Medicare for all’ proposal would push the boundaries of taxing corporations and the rich to fund expanded government programs.
articles.abstract: A ‘Medicare for all’ proposal would push the boundaries of taxing corporations and the rich to fund expanded government programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years after President Trump rode a wave of populist anger into office, some of his top Democratic challengers are calling for a fundamental reordering of American capitalism, arguing that voters will embrace bold plans to reverse decades of rising inequality by raising taxes on corporations and the rich.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Saudi Aramco Announces Plans to Go Public
articles.snippet: The oil-producing giant, Saudi Arabia’s crown jewel, could become the most valuable company in the world.
articles.abstract: The oil-producing giant, Saudi Arabia’s crown jewel, could become the most valuable company in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Saudi Arabia’s giant state-owned oil producer, Saudi Aramco, announced plans on Sunday to go public in what could be the largest initial stock offering ever.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: The Money Farmers: How Oligarchs and Populists Milk the E.U. for Millions
articles.snippet: The European Union spends $65 billion a year subsidizing agriculture. But a chunk of that money emboldens strongmen, enriches politicians and finances corrupt dealing.
articles.abstract: The European Union spends $65 billion a year subsidizing agriculture. But a chunk of that money emboldens strongmen, enriches politicians and finances corrupt dealing.
articles.lead_paragraph: CSAKVAR, Hungary — Under Communism, farmers labored in the fields that stretch for miles around this town west of Budapest, reaping wheat and corn for a government that had stolen their land.
articles.byline: By Selam Gebrekidan, Matt Apuzzo and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: These Machines Can Put You in Jail. Don’t Trust Them.
articles.snippet: Alcohol breath tests, a linchpin of the criminal justice system, are often unreliable, a Times investigation found.
articles.abstract: Alcohol breath tests, a linchpin of the criminal justice system, are often unreliable, a Times investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: A million Americans a year are arrested for drunken driving, and most stops begin the same way: flashing blue lights in the rearview mirror, then a battery of tests that might include standing on one foot or reciting the alphabet.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Push to Raise Minimum Wage Goes Local, at Airports and Hotels
articles.snippet: As efforts stall at the federal level, labor groups are working to lift pay in specific occupations and industries in a growing number of cities.
articles.abstract: As efforts stall at the federal level, labor groups are working to lift pay in specific occupations and industries in a growing number of cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Labor unions and community groups are pursuing an increasingly successful strategy to force employers to pay their workers more: minimum wages for specific occupations and industries.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Teens Love TikTok. Silicon Valley Is Trying to Stage an Intervention.
articles.snippet: American’s big tech companies haven’t had to worry much about competition. Then an addictive Chinese app arrived.
articles.abstract: American’s big tech companies haven’t had to worry much about competition. Then an addictive Chinese app arrived.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Teenagers are gaga for TikTok. That’s why Silicon Valley is so worried about it.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Flood of Oil Is Coming, Complicating Efforts to Fight Global Warming
articles.snippet: New supplies from Brazil, Canada, Guyana and Norway may add to a glut, posing a threat to producers in Saudi Arabia, Russia and the United States.
articles.abstract: New supplies from Brazil, Canada, Guyana and Norway may add to a glut, posing a threat to producers in Saudi Arabia, Russia and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A surge of oil production is coming, whether the world needs it or not.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: As Warren Gains in Race, Wall Street Sounds the Alarm
articles.snippet: With a populist message that promises to rein in corporate excess, Ms. Warren has been facing more hostility from the finance industry than any other candidate.
articles.abstract: With a populist message that promises to rein in corporate excess, Ms. Warren has been facing more hostility from the finance industry than any other candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julia Roberts was making the rounds at Blackstone, and no one at the giant private equity firm was particularly happy to see her.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Inside Ukraine’s Push to Cultivate Trump From the Start
articles.snippet: Former President Petro Poroshenko alternately flattered President Trump, signed deals with U.S. firms and met with Rudolph Giuliani.
articles.abstract: Former President Petro Poroshenko alternately flattered President Trump, signed deals with U.S. firms and met with Rudolph Giuliani.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before a telephone call with Ukraine’s president that prompted an impeachment inquiry, President Trump was exchanging political favors with a different Ukrainian leader, who desperately sought American help for his country’s struggle against Russian aggression.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Lipton and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Walmart’s Strategy When Wading Into Culture Wars: Offend Few
articles.snippet: Walmart has taken stands on several controversial issues, but the retailer has been careful to alienate as few customers as possible while doing so.
articles.abstract: Walmart has taken stands on several controversial issues, but the retailer has been careful to alienate as few customers as possible while doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart is getting out of the vaping business, but still sells cigarettes. It is working to reduce plastic packaging for the products on its shelves, but continues to use plastic grocery bags in its checkout lines. After a gunman killed 22 people at a Walmart in El Paso this summer, the retailer said it would no longer offer certain types of ammunition, but stopped short of barring customers from carrying their guns into stores.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery

articles.headline: I Got Access to My Secret Consumer Score. Now You Can Get Yours, Too.
articles.snippet: Little-known companies are amassing your data — like food orders and Airbnb messages — and selling the analysis to clients. Here’s how to get a copy of what they have on you.
articles.abstract: Little-known companies are amassing your data — like food orders and Airbnb messages — and selling the analysis to clients. Here’s how to get a copy of what they have on you.
articles.lead_paragraph: As consumers, we all have “secret scores”: hidden ratings that determine how long each of us waits on hold when calling a business, whether we can return items at a store, and what type of service we receive. A low score sends you to the back of the queue; high scores get you elite treatment.
articles.byline: By Kashmir Hill

articles.headline: Apple Commits $2.5 Billion to Ease California Housing Crunch
articles.snippet: The plan includes $1 billion for an affordable housing investment fund as well as an effort to help first-time buyers.
articles.abstract: The plan includes $1 billion for an affordable housing investment fund as well as an effort to help first-time buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple on Monday announced a $2.5 billion plan to address the housing crisis in California, becoming the latest big tech company to devote money to a problem that local lawmakers and economists believe it helped create.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Kevin Granville and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Companies Cut Back, but Consumers Party On, Driving the Economy
articles.snippet: Things feel chillier in the executive suite than they do at the mall, and the future of a record expansion hangs in the balance.
articles.abstract: Things feel chillier in the executive suite than they do at the mall, and the future of a record expansion hangs in the balance.
articles.lead_paragraph: “YOLO,” Danielle Walker said, explaining why she had just spent a chunk of her biweekly $900 paycheck on an adorable outfit — quilted navy vest, cranberry plaid riding pants and knit sweater — from the “equestrian shop” at Janie and Jack, the children’s clothing store in the Mall of America where she works.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Ex-Ukraine Ambassador Testified She Felt Threatened by Trump
articles.snippet: House impeachment investigators released the first transcripts of their private interviews, revealing crucial details as the inquiry enters its public phase.
articles.abstract: House impeachment investigators released the first transcripts of their private interviews, revealing crucial details as the inquiry enters its public phase.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Marie Yovanovitch’s public hearing in the impeachment inquiry.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael S. Schmidt
